to schedule your service?** Contact us today to book an appointment with our expert technicians.\n\n## We Have Local Technicians in Your Area\n\nWhether youre looking for *cooktop repair near me* for an electric or gas built-in cooktop, Sears Home Services has the best local repair technicians to serve you. We have thousands of cooktop repair technicians across the US who are thoroughly trained and highly skilled in fixing all types and brands of cooktops.\n\nWe have local pros in your neighborhood for glass cooktop repair and standard electric cooktop repair. When you need stove top repair, trust the #1 provider in the service industry to fix the problem fast.\n\nWhen searching for *gas cooktop repair near me*, you'll find a Sears technician in your area to fix your gas cooktop quickly. We service top brands such as Frigidaire, Whirlpool, Maytag, Bosch and Kenmore, no matter where you bought it.\n\nRegular maintenance of your cooktop can help prevent costly breakdowns and extend its life. Keep your cooktop operating safely and efficiently by scheduling yearly [appliance maintenance](/maintain) service.\n\nFind the parts and accessories you need to keep your cooktop in top shape at [Sears PartsDirect.](https://www.searspartsdirect.com/category/1234570/cooktop-parts)"])</script><script>self.__next_f.push([1,"1e:T1fb6,"])</script><script>self.__next_f.push([1,"## What Is an Electric Range?\n\nAn electric range is a type of kitchen appliance that combines both an electric stove and oven, allowing you to cook on the stovetop and bake or roast within the oven compartment. These ranges are popular for their ease of use, steady heat control, and fewer safety risks compared to gas appliances.\n\n---\n\n![electric-range-components](//images.ctfassets.net/e0821f6q5nel/4I5uGYoLWhlJ9z8UbAhgn7/2c98d4e9ce3b25988c717f4f74f2b30c/electric-range-components.png)\n\n## Core Components of an Electric Range\n\nTo understand how an electric range works, lets first look at its key components:\n\n* __Heating Elements:__ Electric ranges have two types of heating elementsone for the stovetop and one for the oven. Heating elements work by sending a stream of electrical current through a high-resistance wire that heats up as electrons collide with current-resistant metal.\n* __Stovetop Burners:__ Coils elements or radiant surface elements for a ceramic glass top ranges heat up to provide direct heat for pots and pans.\n* __Oven Heating Elements:__ Usually located at the top and bottom of the oven, these elements create the temperature needed for baking and roasting.\n* __Surface Burner Control Switches:__ Also known as burner infinite switches, these components control the heat level of stovetop burners.\n* __Electronic Oven Control Board:__ This circuit board governs oven operations including the bake mode, broil mode and self-cleaning mode.\n* __Oven Temperature Sensor:__ This device senses oven temperature and sends that signal to the electronic oven control board to accurately control oven temperature.\n* __Control Panel:__ Houses oven and stovetop controls that allow you to adjust the oven temperature, timer, and control surface elements.\n* __Electrical Wiring:__ Powers the heating elements and controls, allowing electricity to flow through the appliance safely.\n\n---\n\n## How Electric Stovetop Burners Work\n\nWhen you turn on an electric stovetop burner, a few steps occur to generate heat:\n\n__Step 1:__ Turning burner control knob on the control panel allows electricity to flow to the coil or ceramic element.\n__Step 2:__ The heating elements resistance to the electricity causes it to heat up. This principle, known as Joule heating, is the same process that warms up an electric space heater.\n__Step 3:__ The stovetop burner will continue to heat up until it reaches the desired temperature, and then the control switch maintains that temperature by cycling the element on and off.\n\n---\n\n## How the Electric Oven Works\n\nThe electric oven functions in much the same way as the stovetop but involves more complex temperature control to ensure consistent cooking.\n\n__Step 1:__ When you set the oven to a specific temperature, electricity flows to the ovens heating elements (usually at the top and bottom).\n__Step 2:__ These elements warm up and distribute heat evenly across the oven interior.\n__Step 3:__ The ovens temperature constantly monitors the oven cavity temperature, cycling the heating elements on and off to keep it consistent.\n\n---\n\n![setting-electric-oven-controls](//images.ctfassets.net/e0821f6q5nel/2dy1dPivjv8LU5mYZhiJS7/98633129d34e020c49106923e6c1b8ab/setting-electric-oven-controls.png)\n\n## Oven Heating Options:\n\n* __Bake Setting:__ Activates the bottom heating element, making it ideal for baking.\n* __Broil Setting:__ Activates the top heating element, providing direct heat from above for browning and finishing dishes.\n* __Convection Option (if available):__ A fan circulates hot air, offering more uniform cooking and quicker results.\n\n---\n\n## Advantages of Electric Ranges\n\nElectric ranges have several benefits:\n\n* __Steady, Even Heat:__ Electric burners heat consistently, allowing for precise cooking.\n* __Ease of Installation:__ Most homes are equipped with electrical outlets, while gas lines are less common.\n* __Low Maintenance:__ Electric ranges have fewer parts and are easier to clean, especially with smooth-top surfaces.\n* __Safety:__ No open flame reduces fire risks and eliminates the need for ventilation.\n* __Rebates:__ Using an electric range helps the environment when compared to a gas range, so you can soon get up to an $840 rebate for switching from a gas to electric range under the [HEEHRA](/blog/what-is-heehra) electrification provisions of the 2022 Inflation Reduction Act passed by the U.S. Congress.\n\n---\n\n![cleaning-a-glass-electric-stovetop](//images.ctfassets.net/e0821f6q5nel/5USJvVWBolEh0zTuLPhsUi/f7fc2a4747eba616db27c28c07e9ae9c/cleaning-a-glass-electric-stovetop.png)\n\n## Maintenance Tips for Electric Ranges\n\nTo keep your electric range working efficiently and safely, consider these maintenance tips:\n\n* __Clean Regularly:__ Wipe down the stovetop after each use, and regularly clean oven spills to prevent buildup.\n* __Inspect Heating Elements:__ Check for visible damage, like cracks or worn-out coils, and replace if necessary.\n* __Use Correct Cookware:__ Ensure the cookware is flat-bottomed and appropriate for electric burners.\n* __Professional Maintenance:__ Schedule annual [range maintenance](/maintain) to have a professional inspect the wiring, controls and components to ensure the stove stays in good condition. Immediately schedule [range repair](/repair/range-repair-service) if you notice any issues or failures.\n\n---\n\n## Troubleshooting Common Electric Range Issues\n\nIf your electric range isnt functioning correctly, these DIY troubleshooting tips might help.\n\n### Oven Wont Heat\n\nAn inadequate power supply, wiring failure, bad bake element, defective temperature sensor or failed electronic control board all could all prevent an electric oven from heating. Watch this video from Sears PartsDirect to see how to troubleshoot the problem.\n\n\u003ciframe width=\"660\" height=\"371\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/vew8pn1t6oM\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\n\nIf youre unable to find and fix the oven heating problem yourself, schedule [range repair](/repair) service to have a Sears Home Services technician resolve the issue.\n\n### Surface Element Wont Heat\n\nA failed element, wiring failure or a broken surface element control switch could be the reason that a stovetop element is not working. Follow the DIY troubleshooting steps in this video to resolve the problem on your own.\n\n\u003ciframe width=\"660\" height=\"371\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/ILco1ob6Vps\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\n\nIf youre unable to fix the surface element heating problem on your own, schedule repair service and well send a technician to your home to fix the issue for you.\n\n### Range Wont Power Up\n\nWhen your range doesn't work at all, it's likely that the range has no electrical power for the display or controls. Possible causes are a tripped house circuit breaker for the range, a problem with the outlet cord (not plugged in or broken) or an internal wiring failure. \n\nCheck the house circuit breaker for your range and reset the breaker if you find it tripped.\n\nUnplug the range and check the terminal block on the back of the range for loose wires or broken terminals. Replace the terminal block if damaged.\n\nA blown thermal fuse can prevent the control from powering up on some ranges. Some ranges have a relay control board that supplies power to the display and controls so a failed relay control board could prevent the range from working.\n\nIf youre unable to find the cause of the power problem, schedule [range repair](/repair) service and well send a tech to your home to fix the range for you.\n\n---\n\nUnderstanding the workings of an electric range can help you make the most of this appliance and ensure it operates safely and efficiently for years to come. By knowing how each part functionsfrom the stovetop burners to the ovens heating elementsyoure better equipped to troubleshoot issues, maintain the appliance, and make delicious meals with confidence.\n\n---\n"])</script><script>self.__next_f.push([1,"1f:T1d3d,"])</script><script>self.__next_f.push([1,"Follow these steps to replace a burnt out coil surface element.\n\n![Image of the model number location on a typical stove](//images.ctfassets.net/e0821f6q5nel/3MB1EclZJQr6UBvzAAW7RA/d50c4eac7ef3b13bba7e2eb2bbbe76a2/Image_of_the_model_number_location_on_a_typical_stove.jpg)\n\n## 1. Order the Replacement Part\n\nFind and use the model number of your stove to order the correct replacement element. Youll typically find the model number on the frame of the stove just above the right front leveling leg. Open the bottom storage or broiler drawer to see the model number sticker. On some ranges, the model number is on the side of the oven door.\n\nOnce you find the model number of your stove, look up the replacement part for the burnt out element on the [Sears PartsDirect website](https://www.searspartsdirect.com/) and order the new element.\n\n---\n\n![Image of homeowner shutting off the circuit breaker for the stove](//images.ctfassets.net/e0821f6q5nel/7eU4FKPefemTgd17frLsZR/c7586d82baebdfd63ea434b99c119b16/Image_of_homeowner_shutting_off_the_circuit_breaker_for_the_stove.jpg)\n\n## 2. Disconnect Electrical Power\n\nOnce you receive the replacement part, disconnect power from the stove by unplugging the power cord or shutting off the house circuit breakers for the stove. The 2 circuit breakers for the stove are typically connected together to you just need to shut off a double switch. If you live in a older home with fuses instead of breakers, you need to remove the fuses for the stove to disconnect electrical power.\n\nMake sure the surface burner elements are cool before starting the repair.\n\n---\n\n![Image of homeowner removing the coil stove element image](//images.ctfassets.net/e0821f6q5nel/3vK85ONr8VsHV83iHMOUv4/4bd6f05b0190335b321384d9b1fc1675/Image_of_homeowner_removing_the_coil_stove_element_image.jpg)\n\n## 3. Remove the Element\n\nCarefully pull the element out of its connection terminal, lifting it slightly as you slide it out.\n\n---\n\n![Image of homeowner installing a new surface coil element in a range](//images.ctfassets.net/e0821f6q5nel/6wR9VtK6ormp2Pamw05sYY/a542ee268e00fb1b8b7e2330ab1fc096/Image_of_homeowner_installing_a_new_surface_coil_element_in_a_range.jpg)\n\n## 4. Install the New Element\n\nPush the new coil element into the connection terminal and push it down onto the edge of the drip bowl.\n\n---\n\n## 5. Restore Electrical Power to the Stove\n\nPlug the stove back in or reset the house circuit breakers for the stove to restore electrical power. If your home uses house fuses, reinstall the house fuses for the stove to restore power.\n\n---\n\n## What To Do When the Coil Element Doesnt Heat\n\nWhen a coil surface element doesnt heat, the failure causing the problem isnt always a bad element. Heres a DIY repair video that shows how to diagnose and fix a problem with a coil surface element not heating.\n\n\u003ciframe width=\"660\" height=\"371\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/eLZcldj0J3k\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\n\n---\n\n## Sears Home Services Can Replace a Burnt Out Stove Element When You Have a Glass Top Range\n\nWhen your stove has a ceramic glass top, schedule [range repair near you](/repair/range-repair-service) with a Sears Home Services Technician to replace the burnt out stove element. Our technicians are factory trained on most major brands and are qualified for [LG stove repair](/repair/lg/range), [Maytag stove repair](/repair/maytag/range), [Whirlpool range repair](/repair/whirlpool/range), and more. Safely lifting the glass top and replacing a radiant surface element is a challenge for most appliance repair DIYers. \n\n---\n\n## Keep Your Stove in Top Shape With Annual Professional Maintenance by Sears Home Services\n\nDepend on Sears Home Services to help you keep your stove in top shape with by [scheduling annual stove maintenance checks](/maintain). Our technician will perform the following services during the visit:\n\n* __Check control operation.__  Range controls are checked for accurate temperature control of the oven and stovetop burners. Faulty controls can cause the range to waste energy when overheating occurs.\n* __Examine oven door alignment and clean the oven door gasket.__ A loose door gasket or bent door hinges can prevent the oven door from sealing, allowing heat to escape during baking. Youll wind up paying higher energy bills because the burner ignites more often and stays burning longer to heat the oven. The technician adjusts and cleans the oven door gasket to make sure it seals the oven door properly.\n* __Test oven self-cleaning operation.__ On ranges that have self-cleaning ovens, the service technician checks the control and oven door lock to make sure it stays closed during the self-cleaning cycle. During the self-cleaning operation, oven heats to extremely high temperatures to burn spills and residue inside the oven to ash. To prevent fires, the oven door must remain closed and locked during self-cleaning. If you were to open the door during self-cleaning, a sudden rush of air into the extremely hot oven can cause a serious fire. \n* __Check and clean the stovetop burners.__ The technician cleans and checks electric elements to make sure theyre operating properly and safely. A short circuit in an electric stovetop burner can cause a serious electrocution risk. An element on a glass-top range that overheats can damage the glass top. On a gas range, the technician cleans checks and adjusts the surface burners. A dirty surface burner can fail to ignite  posing a serious safety risk. \n* __Check oven burners or elements.__ The technician examines and adjusts oven burners in a gas range or electric elements in an electric range. Gas oven burners that arent adjusted correctly can fail to heat the oven properly and may emit excessive carbon monoxide. Electric elements that arent heating correctly will fail to heat the oven properly. A shorted electric element also can pose a serious electrocution risk.\n* __Inspect readily accessible electrical wiring.__ The technician will check the wiring on gas and electric ranges, for insulation damage, proper grounding and secure connections. Damaged wiring or wiring thats not secure can cause an electrocution risk. The ground connection dissipates an electrical short to prevent you from getting an electric shock if a loose wire touches metal in the range. \n* __Level the range and check the anti-tip device.__ The technician levels the range to reduce the risk that a pot or pan will accidentally slide off a gas surface burner. Leveling also helps items bake properly in the oven. The anti-tip device is an essential bracket that prevents the range from tipping forward when you open the oven door and extend an oven rack out of the range with a dish on the rack.\n\nHaving your stove professionally cleaned and maintained every year will help keep it operating efficiently and lasting longer.\n\nWe can keep all of your home appliances in top shape when you [schedule our Kitchen \u0026 Laundry Appliance Check-Up](/maintain/kitchen-laundry-appliance-check-up). Our technician will clean and maintain all of your appliances in one convenient visit to keep your home operating smoothly all year long. Additionally, all of your appliances will last longer when you keep them well maintained.\n\nTrust Sears Home Services to help you manage your entire home so you can sit back, relax and enjoy your life with ease.\n\n---"])</script><script>self.__next_f.push([1,"20:T2565,"])</script><script>self.__next_f.push([1,"## The Basics: What Is a Gas Stove?\n\nA gas stove is a cooking appliance that uses natural gas or propane as its fuel source. When ignited, the gas produces a flame that heats cookware directly. This direct heat offers unmatched control, allowing you to make quick adjustments to temperature, which is why gas stoves are often preferred in many kitchens.\n\n---\n\n## How Does a Gas Stove Work?\n\nA gas stove connects to your homes gas supply through a gas line with a shut-off valve. The incoming gas supply then connects to a pressure regulator that limits gas pressure and flow to design specifications for your stove.\n\nFrom the pressure regulator, the gas supply branches out to the cooktop burners and the oven burners. Here are descriptions of those stove systems.\n\n### Cooktop Burner System\n\nHeres how the cooktop burner system works in a gas stove:\n\n* Gas from the pressure regulator first goes to the cooktop burner control valves. \n* When you turn on a cooktop burner, gas travels from the control valve to the burner head. \n* The control valve has an igniter switch that sends current to the spark igniter electrode next to the burner head to ignite the gas when you turn on a cooktop burner. The burner ignites and begins heating.\n* You can adjust the cooktop burner flame by rotating the burner control valve.\n* When youve finished cooking on the burner, you can shut off the control valve and the burner flame will go out.\n\n### How a Gas Oven Works\n\n* When you set your desired temperature and turn the control knob on, the thermostat sends electric current to the glow bar igniter to start the oven. If you have an oven with an electronic control panel, the electronic control board will activate a relay and send current to the glow bar ignition system to light the burner.\n* The igniter heats up and glows to ignite the burner when the safety gas valve opens. For safety, the gas valve in the ignition system wont open until the glow bar gets hot enough to ignite the gas and allows enough electrical current to flow downstream to the current-activated switch on that device.\n* As the glow bar igniter heats up, its electrical resistance decreases to allow more current to flow to the safety gas valve. Once the igniter glow bar is so hot that it allows more than 3 amps of current to the safety gas valve switch, the bi-metal switch on the safety gas valve trips. This opens the gas valve and gas flows to the burner tube and ignites.\n* The glow bar igniter continues to glow as the burner flames heat the oven. When the oven reaches the set temperature, the control shuts off current to the igniter and safety gas valve. The burner shuts off and stays off until oven temperature decreases about 10 degrees below the oven temperature set point. Then the ignition process repeats to light the burner and maintain the set temperature.\n\n---\n\n## Benefits of Cooking with a Gas Stove\n\nThe oven and cooktop of a gas stove offer significant advantages over electric ranges.\n\n### Benefits of a Gas Stovetop\n\n* __Instant Heat:__ Flames appear immediately upon ignition. Fast heating burners save you time when cooking.\n* __Precise Temperature Control:__ You can quickly increase or decrease surface burner heat by adjusting the knob. A gas burner provides consistent heating because it doesnt cycle on and off like an electric surface element does when heating.\n* __Even Heat Distribution:__ Flames wrap around cookware for uniform cooking.\n* __Cost Efficiency:__ Natural gas and propane is often cheaper than electricity for powering stoves.\n\n### Advantages of a Gas Oven\n\n* __Quick Preheating:__ Gas ovens heat up faster than electric ovens because they generate heat directly from the flame.\n* __Moist Baking Environment:__ The combustion process releases moisture, which can help prevent foods from drying outideal for baking and roasting.\n* __Precise Temperature Control:__ Adjusting the oven temperature will result in quicker response in a gas oven. Also, the gas flame provides more immediate and precise heat level adjustments to consistently maintain baking temperature at the chosen setting.\n* __Cost Efficiency:__ Natural gas and propane is often cheaper than electricity for heating the oven.\n\n---\n\n## Tips for Safe and Efficient Gas Stove Use\n\nFollow these expert tips to use your gas stove safely.\n\n### Ensure Proper Ventilation\n\nGas stoves release combustion byproducts, so make sure your kitchen is well-ventilated. Run the range hood when using the gas stove.\n\nKeep the range hood running for a few minutes after you finish cooking or baking to exhaust all combustion fumes out of your kitchen.\n\n### Keep Burners Clean Regularly\n\nClogged burner nozzles can cause combustion problems and affect flame performance. Follow the procedure shown in this popular YouTube video to thoroughly clean stove top burners:\n\n\u003ciframe width=\"660\" height=\"371\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/9m5nF-uvwkI\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\n\n### Turn Off Burners Properly\n\nAlways double-check that burners are completely off after cooking.\n\n### Check for Leaks\n\nPeriodically inspect your gas supply line and connections. \n\nUse soapy water to detect leaksbubbles will form where gas escapes from leaks or loose gas line connections.\n\nIf you ever smell gas, turn off the stove immediately, ventilate the area, and contact your local gas company.\n\n### Avoid Overcrowding the Oven\n\nOvercrowding the oven can block heat circulation, leading to air circulation problems in the oven cavity and uneven cooking.\n\nFollow the tips in this helpful YouTube video to position and use oven racks properly:\n\n\u003ciframe width=\"660\" height=\"371\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/r_tcl5NCDjo\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\n\n### Professional Maintenance\n\nSchedule professional [oven maintenance](/maintain) every year. A qualified service technician will visit your home and perform these essential oven maintenance, inspection and cleaning tasks:\n\n* Inspect gas supply connections.\n* Check the ignition systems.\n* Inspect surface and oven burners and clean them if needed.\n* Examine cooktop and oven flames and adjust the flame settings if necessary.\n* Check the overall cooktop and oven performance.\n* Inspect readily accessible electrical wiring.\n* Level the stove if necessary.\n\nAnnual professional maintenance wont just ensure that the stove works safely and efficiently, it will also help your appliance last longer.\n\n---\n\n## Common Gas Stove Problems and Solutions\n\n### Cooktop Issues\n\n* __Uneven Flame or Yellow Flame:__ Indicates improper gas-to-air ratio. Clean the burner and check for obstructions.\n* __Burner Not Igniting:__ Check the ignition system and ensure the burner is clean and dry. A surface burner igniter switch and a spark module control the sparking for burners. A power supply problem, failed igniter switch, bad spark module or wiring failure in the spark ignition circuit can prevent the electrodes from sparking.\n\n### Gas Oven Problems\n\nFollow these expert troubleshooting tips when you encounter problems with your gas stoves oven.\n\n#### Gas Oven Wont Heat\n\nSeveral different problems can prevent the oven in your gas stove from heating. Follow the tips in this popular YouTube DIY video to fix an oven heating problem in your gas stove:\n\n\u003ciframe width=\"660\" height=\"371\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/iuRrcw6y7Dc\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\n\nIf youre unable to find and fix the oven heating problem yourself, schedule [range repair](/repair/range-repair-service) service and well send a Sears Home Services technician to your home to resolve the issue.\n\n#### Oven Temperature is Wrong\n\nIf the oven isn't heating to the baking temperature you set  it's too hot or not hot enough  the oven temperature sensor could be malfunctioning. Or the problem could be with the electronic oven control board, which controls oven functions.\n\nYou can test the oven temperature sensor probe by unplugging the range and measuring sensor probe resistance using a multimeter. It should measure about 1,080 ohms of resistance through most probes at room temperature.\n\nRefer to the tech sheet for the probe's resistance specification for your range. You can likely find the tech sheet in the control console or taped to the back of the range. Replace the oven temperature sensor probe if the multimeter doesn't measure the correct resistance through the probe. If the probe is okay, you might need to replace the electronic oven control board.\n\nIf youre unable to find and fix the cause of this problem on your own, schedule [stove repair](/repair/range-repair-service) service and well fix the issue for you.\n\n---\n\nGas stoves continue to be a favorite among home cooks. Their straightforward yet effective design combines practicality with precise performance, making them indispensable in kitchens across the country.\n\nWhether youre simmering a delicate sauce or searing a steak, understanding how your gas stove works empowers you to make the most of this versatile appliance. Plus, with proper care and maintenance, your gas stove will serve you reliably for years to come.\n\nSears Home Services is standing by to help you with gas stove maintenance and repairs any time you need them. Trust us to handle all of your home appliance needs.\n\n---\n"])</script><script>self.__next_f.push([1,"21:T218b,"])</script><script>self.__next_f.push([1,"First of all, if youre nervous about working on your gas oven (or not completely confident in your DIY appliance repair abilities) then youll need to [oven repair service](/repair/oven-repair-service) to have a Sears Home Services technician diagnose and repair your oven when it wont heat. Safety should always be your highest priority when fixing applianceseven if you need to have someone repair your oven for you.\n\nEven if you're sure that you'll have an appliance technician complete the oven repair, it doesnt hurt to understand the troubleshooting and repair process involved in fixing a gas oven that wont heat. There's a chance that you can follow some of the troubleshooting steps described below and safely fix the oven yourself.\n\nIf you want some practical troubleshooting advice to see if you can fix a non-heating gas oven yourself, you're in the right place. Carefully follow the troubleshooting and diagnostic advice described below to repair a gas oven that isn't heating.\n\n## Basic Troubleshooting Steps To Fix a Gas Oven That Wont Heat\n\nWhen troubleshooting any appliance failure, start with the basics. Sometimes a simple fix does the trick.\n\n### Check the Gas Supply\n\nJust about anyone can follow these basic tips to check the gas supply going to the range or wall oven:\n\n* If youre troubleshooting the oven on a gas range, turn on a surface burner to see if its getting gas. If a surface burner works, then you know that your oven should be getting gas as well.\n* If the surface burner doesnt work, check the gas supply cut-off valve for your stove to make sure that it's open. \n* If youre troubleshooting a wall oven, check to see if the broil burner gets gas and heats up (if your wall oven has a separate broil burner). If you have a double oven, you can check to see if the 2nd oven is heating. If other burners in a wall oven are heating, then you know that the inoperative oven burner should be getting gas as well.\n* If no burners in your wall oven are heating, check the gas supply cut-off valve for the oven to make sure that its open.\n* If gas supply valve for your stove or wall oven is open and youre not getting gas to the appliance, check other gas appliances in your home such as the gas dryer. If your entire home is without gas, check the main gas cut-off valve for your house. Open the main cut-off valve if its shut. This may restore gas to your oven and other appliances so they work properly.\n\nIf the main gas cut-off valve for your home is open and no appliances are getting gas, then you need to contact your gas supplier to figure out whats wrong.\n\nIf other appliances are getting gas but you suspect that your wall oven or stove isnt getting gas, then youll likely need to have a plumber or gas technician from your gas supplier fix the gas supply going to your stove or wall oven.\n\n### Check the Service Cut-Off Valve\n\nMany gas ranges have a service cut-off valve on their pressure regulator at the back of the stove. It shuts off the gas supply to the oven but not the surface burners. \n\nIf the surface burners on your gas stove work but the oven burners arent getting gas, make sure that the lever on the service cut-off valve is in the open position.\n\n![Checking the service cut-off valve](//images.ctfassets.net/e0821f6q5nel/3sUOqIPGTYVRNvsIYQHlov/4b8cffc6edcafbfed88dfb940a91afd0/Check_the_service_cut-off_valve.png)\n\n## Advanced Troubleshooting For a Gas Oven That Wont Heat\n\nWhen the basic troubleshooting steps dont do the trick, youll need to conduct some advanced troubleshooting to fix a gas oven that isnt heating. Nothings better than a YouTube video to describe advanced troubleshooting for a non-heating gas oven. Follow the steps in this Sears PartsDirect YouTube video to fix your gas oven:\n\n\u003ciframe width=\"660\" height=\"371\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/iuRrcw6y7Dc\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\n\nAfter the video goes through some of the basic troubleshooting steps described above, the following diagnostic techniques are used to figure out whats wrong with a gas oven that wont heat.\n\n### Test the Oven Igniter\n\nMost gas ovens use a glow bar ignition system that uses this ignition process:\n\n1. The control sends electrical current through the igniter and safety gas valve to light the oven burner and heat the oven.\n2. The igniter heats up but the safety gas valve won't open to ignite the burner until the igniter reaches a safe ignition temperature.\n3. As the igniter heats up, the resistance of the igniter element decreases and more current flows through the circuit to the safety gas valve.\n4. When the igniter reaches ignition temperature, its resistance is low enough to allow enough current to flow through the circuit and open the safety gas valve.\n5. Gas flows through the open valve and to the burner and ignites.\n\nThe number 1 failure preventing a gas oven from heating is a weak igniter. The igniter wont get hot enough to allow adequate current to flow to the safety valve so the valve wont open to let gas flow to the burner for ignition.\n\nThats why we recommend testing the oven igniter first.\n\nPull the bottom panel out of your cold oven. Start the oven and see if the igniter glows.\n\nIf the igniter glows but the burner doesnt ignite because the gas valve doesnt open, then youll likely need to replace the igniter. As noted in the video, if you're uncertain whether your glowing igniter has failed, you can [schedule service for your oven](/repair/oven-repair-service) and have a Sears service technician check the amp draw through the igniter circuit.\n\nIf youre convinced that the oven igniter is bad, then you can [order a new igniter](https://www.searspartsdirect.com/category/1234574/range-parts) and replace the igniter. Replacing a gas oven igniter is a relatively safe repair that most DIYers can accomplish on their own because it doesnt involve disconnecting any gas lines in the oven. Follow the steps in this YouTube video to replace the oven igniter:\n\n\u003ciframe width=\"660\" height=\"371\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/DTXwfTiFZfE\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\n\nNow, if the igniter __doesnt__ glow, then the igniter element may be broken. Youll need a [multimeter](https://www.sears.com/craftsman-multimeter-digital-with-8-functions-and-20/p-03482141000P) to check resistance through the igniter so see if the element is bad.\n\nUnplug the range. For safety, always disconnect power before checking resistance. To check the resistance of the igniter, put the meter leads on the igniter terminals. If you measure between 10 and 2,500 ohms, then you know your igniter is okay.\n\nIf the igniter measures no continuity, then you need to replace the igniter.\n\n## Test the Safety Gas Valve\n\nNext, check resistance through the safety gas valve. The meter should measure less than 5 ohms of resistance through the terminals on the safety gas valve. \n\nIf the safety gas valve measures no continuity, you can [have a Sears technician replace that part](/repair/range-repair-service). Replacing the safety gas valve involve disconnection of gas lines inside the oven.\n\n## Check the Wiring and Control Board\n\nWhen you find that the igniter and safety gas valve appear to be okay, youll need to check wiring in the ignition circuit and the electronic oven control board. \n\nWith electrical power still disconnected from the oven, access the back of the electronic oven control board and check resistance through the ignition circuit wires connected to the electronic control board. \n\nIf you measure the same resistance through the ignition circuit as you measured through the igniter (between 10 and 2,500 ohms), then replace the electronic control board because you know that the wiring through the ignition circuit is okay.\n\nIf you measure infinite resistance (also called an open load) through the ignition circuit wiring, then you'll need to trace the wires through the ignition circuit and repair the broken wire (with the oven still disconnected from electrical power).\n\nThese DIY troubleshooting steps should help you fix a gas oven that isnt heating in most situations. If you cant figure out whats wrong and fix the oven on your own, dont hesitate to [schedule oven repair service](/repair/oven-repair-service) and well send a Sears Tech right out to your home to fix the oven."])</script><script>self.__next_f.push([1,"a:[\"$\",\"$L18\",null,{\"pageMetadata\":{\"title\":\"Expert Cooktop Repair Services | Sears Home Services\",\"name\":\"Trust Sears Home Services for professional cooktop repairs.
